posts.title: The complexity of FB ‘Dislike’ button and why should marketers embrace it
posts.title_plain: The complexity of FB ‘Dislike’ button and why should marketers embrace it
posts.content:
Facebook has become an integral part of our daily-life. We share everything we want and people like everything they want! And with the time situation has gone like this

It is weird but what can as users what can we do, we want to show that we have seen it, absorbed it and we care. So do we press ‘Like’? Just to say “I hear you” – I empathise.

The problem is, how can we ‘Like’ that our friend’s moggy has died or they are still stuck working for a boss they detest? There is the option to comment, but that exposes us a little more. We don’t necessarily have the right words for the moment. Or perhaps we really can’t be bothered to find them. So we are stuck.

As social media has become the default form of “being in touch”, this issue has created some moral complexity for us Facebook junkies. And although we could just pick up the phone and say “sorry to hear your news…” we tend to need a shortcut – a holding position until we next see our friend. And finally it seems Mark Zuckerberg has acknowledged the problem with his announcement of a pending Dislike button.

This is potentially exciting news as it will allow us to express appropriate empathy, albeit at a superficial level.

However, the word Facebook chooses to describe the button when it goes live will be interesting. Choose the wrong word and it could be seen as the “Hate” button. Careful thought needs to be given to ensure it doesn’t become a new tool for bullying in the hands of the troll community.

And what about brands? Us marketers have been able to get away with a lot on Facebook up until now. Poorly executed content, random posts, experimental campaigns under the guise of “test and learn”. Sure, there are comments, and we can measure shares and compare post performance. But there’s nothing quite like seeing a number of Dislikes piling up on a post or ad you thought was really cool. It’s a new KPI waiting to happen.

However, this is where the Dislike button will also bring opportunity. We will have to be on our game, ensuring the right content gets to the right audience. And the Dislike button could actually help us understand instantly when we’ve got it wrong.

On the flipside, no doubt some brands will actively court Dislikes if they want to be regarded as edgy, controversial or see it as a route to publicity. You can see the Buzzfeed headline now, “10 most Disliked adverts this week.” Or perhaps more realistically, “10 most hated cat videos”.

Facebook will have an interesting balance to strike in order to not bite the hand that feeds them. They need to grow ad spend, but will advertisers get nervous that their content it be judged negatively as well as positively?

We believe this is a challenge brands and marketers should embrace. It will make us better in terms of credible social marketing.

posts.title: Smart Wearables: The Next In-Store Shopping Buddies
posts.title_plain: Smart Wearables: The Next In-Store Shopping Buddies
posts.content:
Wearables are coming to a store near you. According to April 2015 research by PowerReviews, 30% of US smartphone owners owned or planned to purchase a wearable device in the next 12 months. Among this group, 82% wanted such devices to enhance their in-store experience, and nearly half wanted to leverage wearables to save time when shopping.

Respondents hoped wearables wouldn’t let them forget a loved-one’s birthday or that special anniversary ever again, as 28% said they would be interested in receiving event reminders while shopping in-store. One-quarter wanted alerts to long lines in stores, emphasizing the need for retailers to integrate their online-offline presence. Some consumers have already expressed interest in using wearables for mobile payments, and 22% of PowerReviews respondents were interested in touchless or one-click payments. Rounding out the list were interactive maps, cited by one-fifth of respondents.

(Source- eMarketer)

On the other side, associates could also leverage wearables—and the data that comes along with them—to create personalized and seamless in-store experiences. A March 2015 study by Salesforce.com looked at wearable technology adoption among business professionals. When the research asked US enterprise wearable adopters about their current or planned customer-facing uses of wearable tech, 41% cited loyalty rewards. Using wearables at the point of sale, for immersive experiences or for location-sensing technology were each cited by 40%. Similar numbers also used or intended to use wearables to serve targeted ads and offers or provide an integrated shopping experience.

More than one-third of PowerReviews respondents who were interested in wearables wanted to make their lives easier, and retailers looking to satisfy this demand during the shopping process must determine how to best merge these digital devices with the physical store.

posts.title: Are you a digital CMO? Here are 7 things you need to know about ‘PAID SOCIAL’
posts.title_plain: Are you a digital CMO? Here are 7 things you need to know about ‘PAID SOCIAL’
posts.content:
As a digital marketer, we’re sure you have a definite marketing budget for using paid social advertising. Today’s paid social landscape is way different from what it is used to be in 2013 or before that;  thanks to emergent channels and the rapid ascendance of new ad types from the major social players. So, considering all the aspects of the changing social paid media scenario, it has become necessary to take a deep dive into where your paid social funds are going and for that you need to know some seven key factors deciding the paid social structure.

Bring some coffee and let’s get started with some valuable inputs from Scott Rayden- Chief Revenue Officer for 3Q Digital, a Harte Hanks company. He is responsible for leading marketing, sales, and the overall revenue growth of 3Q Digital nationwide.

Paid Social Channels Cover Almost The Entire Funnel: Regardless of the budget size, paid social can cover almost the entire funnel. Few years back, there was a salient argument that paid social was good for brand awareness and not much else but today, very paid social channel worth investing in has robust targeting, attractive ad types (including video ads), better conversion tracking, more flexible bidding, retargeting and even more advanced ways to put first-party data into play to engage people already affiliated with your brand. PERIOD!

Paid social is the best to market yourself in an interesting way without burning a hole in your pocket. Even if you’re starting with mere 500 bucks to spend initially, you can play well! Tip- “Get your CRM data uploaded into Facebook or Twitter to target the folks who already know you, create a lookalike or similar audience to reach a new base of users who look a lot like your customers, and watch the data roll in”, Scott Rayden- Chief Revenue Officer for 3Q Digital.

Mobiles top the chart: Earlier this year, Google rolled out ‘Mobilegeddon’ that made it necessary to have a mobile friendly websites. Within few months of this huge algorithm change, many studies have shown incredible revenue surging on various social channels. Reportedly, mobile accounted for a whopping 88% of Twitter’s total advertising revenue and 76% of Facebook’s total advertising revenue. Mobiles and smartphones are the next big universe for the digital marketers, this is gradually engulfing the whole scenario as people now-a-days spend half of their time on surfing mobile internet. Although for e-commerce sites, mobile still struggles at capturing the ultimate conversion but on the rest of the platforms, videos are just unrivalled form of marketing. But remember- “When you’re pulling users off their mobile feeds and onto your mobile site, that experience has to be smooth and compelling to justify the click. Make sure your messaging, tone and creative are aligned from ad to landing page”, Scott Rayden- Chief Revenue Officer for 3Q Digital.

Videos are the Showstopper: Facebook has native videos,  YouTube is growing so fast and other popular video platforms like Vimeo are experiencing a huge footfall and the craze cannot be measured in units. Even Twitter, Instagram and others have developed video ads now. Basically, advertisers now have the ability to combine TV commercials with digital-era targeting and relatively low costs. And paid social video is an outstanding way to test out potential TV content before stepping onto TV ads.

“If you don’t have video assets yet, now is the time to develop them; the channel capabilities are viable now, and CPCs are only going up as more content gets pushed out”, Scott Rayden.

Facebook is nailing it: Marketers should know that FB is one of the best platforms for targeting and retargeting and the introduction of carousel ads and video ads that take users off the platform and onto advertisers’ websites is just amazing. But then, then, then it doesn’t mean that you will put all your paid social budget into Facebook. “The other channels, particularly Twitter, have different audiences well worth reaching and inherent advantages worth testing. But there’s really no reason to ignore Facebook at this point, no matter how poorly its ads might have performed when you first tested them out”, Scott Rayden.

Stand patient with Twitter Campaigns: We can’t deny that Twitter’s user data isn’t as good as Facebook’s but then it has real targeting implications: Interests are inferred, demographics (including gender) are inferred, and so on…so, in terms of organising a Twitter Campaign, you need to be patient as on Twitter, the initial targeting is going to be fuzzier and unlikely to perform as desired. “In any case, Twitter definitely has its strengths, especially for real-time event-based marketing, well-known brands and all things sports-related. But remember not to expect any campaign numbers to sparkle in the first few weeks; give your team time to roll up their sleeves and respond to the data before you make any big decisions on budget”, Scott Rayden.

LinkedIn is a falling star: This platform has definitly grabbed a lot of decent attention previously but currently it’s falling behind. “No doubt, LinkedIn still has one huge advantage over its competitors: It lets advertisers target B2B decision makers on a business-oriented social publisher but as compared to its competitors, which have been introducing new ad types and targeting features at much higher frequencies, it has work to do to position itself to earn more marketing budget”, Scott Rayden.

The Social Paid market will get more crowded in near future: Observing the current social trend and the demand for the same, the race is not expected to slow-down in coming digital years. More and more social paid media players will plug in and they will explore more in terms of advertising so you as a marketer need to keep a constant hawk eye on the developments. It is jnust that you need to understand the game well and play accordingly on a fair basis. “Just make sure your team is aligning your goals with the right channels and ad types and testing promising new features as they become available — which, as we all know, is just about every week. Good luck!”, Scott Rayden.

posts.title: Twitter Direct Message Changes Open Ways for Positive Marketing
posts.title_plain: Twitter Direct Message Changes Open Ways for Positive Marketing
posts.content:
If we talk about Twitter and brands in economic terms then both of them are ‘complimentary goods'; how? Twitter needs brands because it gets money from them and brands need Twitter because they get marketing and networking objectives fulfilled through this social platform. The only glitch here is that the brands are often scared of Twitter as consumers get an open platform to complain about the bad services, ethics and products. Twitter is so instant and open that it is just impossible for Twitter to hide the shoddy reviews and feedbacks. So, some great minds at Twitter came up with a plan of direct messages. Popularly known as DMs, it is the lesser-utilised feature of Twitter. Taking it further, Twitter decided to change the working of DMs for a better communication between brands and consumers. Let’s know the change in a more detailed way

The Big Change Twitter Has Planned

DMs will now have a maximum word limit of 10,000 characters (a bit of an essay) whereas earlier it was restricted to 140 characters (the same as a tweet). In our opinion, this is a much needed change for both brands and Twitter. Here’s why:

  • It will move customer service to a private forum as now brands will get a room to send someone an email address or phone number to call to actually deal with the situation. Both the parties can interact clearly and properly.
  • Brands can now manage the situations and issues more easily and on the other side consumers aren’t limited to 140 characters and will receive timely and meaningful responses
  • Aah! Long conversations will be the most winning point of this DMs change. According to a recent report, Twitter’s 316 million monthly active users spend an average of 170 minutes per month on the site. The longer DMs turns Twitter’s messaging feature from a short, snappy conversation platform to a place where people can actually debate, make and share detailed plans and generally hold lengthy conversations leading to a longer stay on site and thus more likely to see featured ads. Twitter can leverage this feature in reporting baback better numbers to their board. Win Win!
  • So, for all Twitter DM haters…here’s some good news! We do agree that for few people messages like “thanks for following, check out my wares at www.buymywares.com” were extremely annoying and impersonal. In contrary to the previous scenario, messages will now be more purposeful and specific satiating the needs for all kind of users.
  • This big DM change will surely affect brands’ follower base in a positive way. If a consumer send a query or a complaint then to get a reply back, the consumers still have to follow the specific brand. This will automatically open the gates for more people/ users to view the brands’ content leading to a wider network. On the other hand, if the brands are able to deal with the customer service issues well then nothing like it! It will add up to the brands’ credibility.

So, as a brand or an organisation if you’re on Twitter then this e increase in character limit could really help if used in a tactical way. And for those who are not on Twitter yet, more reasons to be on it!

posts.title: Pinterest launches buyable Pins for iOS users
posts.title_plain: Pinterest launches buyable Pins for iOS users
posts.content:
Later in the month of June, Pinterest launched its buyable Pins on iPhones and iPads and made it possible for all the iOS users across the United States to purchase products of their preference straight from the site.

The users can now see the buyable Pins in the home feeds, boards and search results. It also includes the cost of the desired item in blue colour along with a blue “BUY IT” tab to mark the particular product’s availability. Also, users can now search for a product by its price on the list that means Pinterest is filtering the search results according to the end users’ pocket size.

“Say you’re on the hunt for a new jacket. Try a search, then swipe through all the buyable Pins at the top of your search results. Filter by price to hone in on the right Pin for you”, as quoted in an official Pinterest blog.

Have a look

This new Pinterest iOS app menu now also includes “Shop” and “Shop our picks” categories where users can browse buyable Pins. According to the official sources, the “Shop” category will include the latest buyable Pins, while the “Shop our picks” category lists products “hand-picked” by Pinterst.

Within one month of launch, Pinterest currently has more than million buyable pins from a various retailers including big names like Macy’s, Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom, to name a few. They also have some e-commerce sites powered by Demandware and Shopify stores in their kitty. The users can search buyable pins from a specific retailer as well. For that they have to go to the retailer’s Pinterest profile and tap on the “Shop Pins” button located on the right side of the retailer’s profile.

While the current app is available only on iOS devices, Pinterest says it is planning a same release for desktop and Android users too in near future as the number of smartphone users is increasing at a rapid pace.

posts.title: Shopo: Snapdeal’s counter to Olx and Quikr
posts.title_plain: Shopo: Snapdeal’s counter to Olx and Quikr
posts.content:
India’s one of the largest online e-commerce sites, Snapdeal is re-launching Shopo and this time as a mobile app focused goods and services marketplace. They have decided to launch the app two years after it acquired the startup for an undisclosed sum.

Shopo is the first mobile app only play offering from Snapdeal and comes days after rival ecommerce company, Bengaluru-based Flipkart announced that it will be shifting to a mobile only strategy from September; sheer co-incidence, isn’t it? Their zero commission marketing strategy for Shopo app will see e the will see the Delhi-headquartered ecommerce company compete head-to-head with mobile and web classifieds majors such as Naspers-backed OLX mobile app and Tiger Global-Warburg Pincus backed Quikr mobile app.

Speaking about the re-launch of Shopo, Kunal Bahl, CEO- Snapdeal happily stated, “We are positioning Shopo for India’s 32-million small and medium sellers who necessarily don’t own a business to sell goods”. The Shopo app will also act as an appendage to Snapdeal that means it only take registered business as sellers. A registered business seller should first have a TIN/TAN number or a value-added tax (VAT) registration number and then gradually they achieve the seller position on Snapdeal. These sellers can be from any background, homemakers, amateur artists, small shop owners, and designers, small manufacturers; to name a few. Both Shopo and Snapdeal is a business wing of Delhi-based Jasper Infotech.

How will Shopo operate as?

Shopo mobile app will operate as a separate platform apart from other wings. This will solely be headed by Sandeep Komaravelly. Komaravelly was earlier the senior vice-president, marketing and communications, at Snapdeal. “Shopo will operate as a zero commission marketplace, and Snapdeal will also not be charging potential sellers’ registration costs”, said Komaravelly.

Snapdeal cofounder and chief executive Kunal Bahl further added that the company will consider adding payment gateways down the line too, which will later act as a revenue generator.

No doubt that India’s ecommerce marketplace is growing day by day with the increase in demand. As a result the marketplaces have been attempting to on-board large quantities of sellers on to their platforms and in return it plays a critical role amongst the sellers in garnering critical risk of capital funding.

posts.title: ’90s Banner Ads: Still Relevant For Today’s Advertising World
posts.title_plain: ’90s Banner Ads: Still Relevant For Today’s Advertising World
posts.content:
Advertising world has become astronomical all of a sudden…mobile, gadgets, interactive TV and other updated visions of the future are dominating industry headlines currently. But whenever a headline includes the word “banner,” it’s typically adjacent to something along the lines of “being backdated” or “dying”.

Nobody pays attention to what is popular as display advertising- the euphemism being used to make the banner ads more appealing and aesthetically pleasing. The banner ads were cheap and still considered as an unremarkable thing of the past advertising market. But the technology we use to power display has, in fact, become the engine that powers the most interesting aspects of advertising today.

Most advertising and marketing technology companies don’t think of the creative as a constraint. Most important are the individual we’re reaching and the data available to choose what to show someone where and when.

Display advertising has the power to encompass any ad idea targeted to an individual or a group of members. The whole engulfing part is about how the data is being presented and how an individual is targeted through the media channel. Today, the technology has advanced so much that we no longer need to rely solely on the invented “personas” or standard audience segments (e.g., stay-at-home mom, single millennial) based on general assumptions or standalone behavioral data. We are now capable enough to reach the target audience more easily regardless of whether they fit within a marketer’s standard persona or not. As data trends emerge and consumers’ habits change, the implications surrounding display advertising is also changing.

Fractured Media Paving Way for New Generation Ads

With the growing media forms in the digital domain and the rapidly increasing number of visitors clicking on ads continues to dwindle, new generation ad formats are continually invented. Although these new generation ads look less like advertising but they indeed show strong resemblance with “advertorial” found in magazines of yesteryear.

Native formats and other inventive ad styles are popping up, such as new formats from Facebook and Pinterest and even the recent Vessel 5-second video ad (introduced by former Hulu CEO Jason Kilar). Expect this to become more and more evident over time, because the creation of these highly visual ad formats is becoming increasingly automated.

Eventually, we’ll see advertisers give one set of creative that can turn into hundreds — or even thousands — of different ad formats. But these ads will still be called as “display advertising” only.

Video Ads, the new most adorable kid in town

According to a recent Business Insider report, Video is quickly replacing static display advertising. The report noted that video will account for 41% of total desktop display-related spending by the year 2020. In-stream video ads that play at the start, during and after video content also showed a record breaking performance than standard display units, which is reflected in the format’s high prices.

Because of the high production costs and much need of time, video ads are bit difficult to adopt but there is no doubt that in coming years, we will be equipped with more advanced options for integrating video into display advertising both as a branding and direct response tool.

Social Video Platforms like YouTube have introduced direct shopping from videos feature and Social Media Platforms like Facebook, Instagram and Pinterest are continuously looking for new ways to evolve the display ad into an engagement and branding vehicle.

But it is an irony only that video advertising is too targeted using the same tools as display advertising.

In Search of Unified and Customised Ads

In a report by MyBuys, three out of four shoppers are willing to allow retailers to use in-store purchase data for personalization purposes. The report facts clearly showed that consumers get frustrated and annoyed when marketing messages do not take into account their past browsing behaviors. In fact, 53% of shoppers surveyed said they would purchase more from retailers that suggest products based on their browsing behaviors. Thus, this shows that they look for a more unified and customised ad as per their choice which is once again directly relevant to the display ad mannerism used in ’90s.

The Consolidation of Media Departments

‘Since the year 2014, the mobile internet usage growth has grown up to 23% and currently growing at a jet-speed’ as pointed by Kleiner Perkins’ Mary Meeker. Evidently, mobile advertising format is for mobile users only, which is a part of what is known as ‘one-to-one advertising’. Isn’t it shows a strong connection with the term du jour used for banner ads created back in the 1990s?

We do say that we have incorporated a lot of new ideas in advertising but in the race we have overlooked the relevance and importance of banner advertising. If you love advertising then surely you will find that learning from the ‘90s Banner Ad still apply today as well!

posts.title: Underexposed: Bringing Homeless into Light
posts.title_plain: Underexposed: Bringing Homeless into Light
posts.content:
We have seen a lot of black-and-white portraits of the homeless but this time they are being shown in colour, in a different light literally. With his new spectacular ‘Underexposed’ series of photographs, California native and social activist, Aaron Drape strives to make the homeless people “as visually appealing as possible”. He wants to bring color into the lives of homeless people in California- “bring them into the light and out of the shadows for others to view and appreciate”.

Being a professor of photography at Chico State University, Draper got inspired by the works on Steinbeck for this particular project. It has a simple premise: to take beautiful, well lit portraits of the homeless after all we tend to overlook things which are not pretty.

“Steinbeck has influenced me and informed my view of the world,” Draper explains on his website. In Of Mice and Men and The Grapes of Wrath, I was introduced to a philosophy regarding society, about economic disparity and Steinbeck’s efforts to shed light on the problems of the poor in our society. Steinbeck hoped to bring about societal change, just as I hope to enable people to gain a more humane view of the homeless.”

“I use lighting as a way to interest the viewer in the subjects shown, I hope to enable people to gain a more humane view of the homeless”, he further added with a hope of consideration from the society.

“When it comes to social activism, you achieve greater public awareness by communicating hope as opposed to hopelessness”

“When something is underexposed, it means it’s lacking light; there are few details in the shadows”

“Using a strobe helps illuminate my subjects, bringing them into the light and out of the shadows for others to view and appreciate”

“If I’m able to affect the way that one person views the homeless, I will have considered my series a success. And that gives me hope,” Draper saysexperssing his inner views.

We hope your noble initiative will pave its way for a deeper thought…

posts.title: Wyatt Neumann, you’ll be missed badly
posts.title_plain: Wyatt Neumann, you’ll be missed badly
posts.content:
The global creative community bid adieu to one of its bravest creative asset, Wyatt Neuman. Neuman was an extremely multi-talented creative/director/photographer known for challenging the usual assumptions of the society. His works towards making the world a better and informed place to live in is just unbelievable. Reeving up his works in any explanations would be an insult to it; his death is a great loss for all of us hailing from the creative sector.

Neuman had suffered a brain aneurysm while driving his motorcycle in Delaware, causing him to lose control of his vehicle. He is survived by his wife Jena and two children Stella and Takota.

Although, Neumann has worked for a number of popular agencies including Decon and R/GA as a creative director but perhaps he was best known for his photography. One of the major turning point in his photography career was his last year’s controversial photography exhibit, “I Feel Sorry for Your Children” , created in response to the social-media outcry over photos he took of his daughter Stella during a cross-country road trip. The exhibit included some intimate images of his daughter Stella in playful moments, the only problematic angle was in some snaps; she was nude or partially clothed.

(Some photographs from the series)

After he posted the photographs on social media platforms, it sparked criticism from all nook and corner as being pedophilic. It was quite senseless and unethical blame as the exhibit was a powerful attempt to reclaim the innocence of the parent-child bond in a society that has become tainted with darker and more sinister points of view. There’s a six minute long documentary even on the same where he spoke about bravery and creativity during a presentation for the Advertising Club of New York. Recalling the experience during the whole controversy related to the “I Feel Sorry…” series, Neumann expressed his views reeved in some inspiring words of encouragement during the presentation: “When you get stuck in these situations, if you’ve done everything up until that point with integrity, if you stand on your own two feet and you believe in what you do, then it’s not that difficult to be brave. You’re not making a choice at that moment where the. . . possibility of failure is really that clear because you just follow your heart. Your heart and your integrity give you something to dig your heels into, a place to stand when the shit-storm comes your way.”

Neumann was a popular public figure known for using his photography and creative connections to help the community. The biggest example was the start of “Bring Back the Boardwalks,” organisation that sought to provide relief to Hurricane Sandy victims through art-related fundraisers.

There is no single doubt on the fact that he Neumann has touched upon many lives through his boisterous meaningful conversation and debate via his amazing works in the most unexpected situations and with unsuspecting people. One of his colleagues at Decon, Misha Louy (partner/executive producer) described him as a limited edition human, one of those super rare ones that you may scour forever looking for.

âHe taught me to stand strong by my principles yet never judge someone for having their own. Wyatt knew how to show up, anytime I needed him for the tough moments, to celebrate triumphs or just to burn the day away with fun. Nobody cared more about his family, friends and strangers more than Wyatt. His unique spirit will live on through his beautiful family and the wide array of close friends that he has brought together so tightly since his passing. I really look up to him; he was a true hero of mine and will always be. I love you Wyatt Neumann”, she added.

People with such great inborn talent, understanding of the societal values and norms with a unique creative bent of mind are hard to find in this crazily moving virtual world. And when they leave us, it is a great loss in the creative journey of life. This blog is a tribute to Wyatt Neumann, may his soul rest in peace…ending here with teary eyes!

posts.title: Time to get personal on Facebook for Organic Growth
posts.title_plain: Time to get personal on Facebook for Organic Growth
posts.content:
Time to get personal on Facebook for Organic GrowthIt is a great matter of concern that the organic growth for digital marketers is in steep decline. Where global brands shake in their boots at the prospect of Google making further major changes to its algorithms, the marketers on the other hand struggle to keep up with the impact of those changes in the marketing world. Recently, Google’s new mobile-friendly ranking factor algorithm has led to hysteria dubbed ‘mobilegeddon’.
It has now become totally visible that marketers like to feel that they are in control of some major player in the market. Given a chance to grant wishes to marketing teams, control over audience reach and brand visibility would feature on the top but due to the rapid, sudden and consistent changes in Google and Facebook alogorithms every year, a sense of doubt has been cast over the marketing wish list. Not only that, the ability to reach out to consumers and grow organically has fallen dramatically.

Now obviously marketers worldwide will see this time as the most worrisome but it is a golden opportunity indeed. Think of the situation like this – the industry is at a bit of a crossroads and with the right guidance and technology in place, the path to success will become much clearer. Brands must prepare themselves for a life without organic reach.

Organic reach ending…really?

Along with Google, marketers also have to grapple with Facebook’s algorithmic updates as FB contributes to the major chunk of the social media engagement. More than 757 million users log-on to the social network each day so the potential reach for brands is colossal. In the inception days of FB, the ability to build communities of fans, and then maintain contact and encourage engagement using content published to fansâ News Feeds was seen as a huge opportunity. But just when everything seemed to be going so smooth and glitch free, FB comes up with a big change in 2012. They put a big ‘STOP’ sign and restricted the level of content published from brand pages to about 16 per cent.

In December 2013, Ogilvy conducted a research and according to that further algorithm changes reduced the total reach to 8.7 per cent and to worsen the situation this figure further plummeted to an all-time low of just 6 per cent. It looked like a some kind of joke for all big companies and brands who were earlier enjoying more than 500,000 âLikesâ on their social pages because their organic reach fall to two per cent only…nightmare at its worst!

So there will be no surprise if this figure hits zero. It could have been sooner than we think if Facebook continues to roll out algorithmic updates like the one we saw in January 2015. To choose which stories to display, the new system ranks each possible story by looking at thousands of factors relative to each person. This means that when you click send on a post, it may now be filtered out. For example, out of 1,500 posts a user could see when they log on, the News Feed will now display only 300 or so. As more and more businesses and users post and share articles, videos and pictures, the chance of a key promotion, perhaps the launch of an e-commerce brandâs new clothing line, not reaching your desired destination grows.

This was even not enough, to add some more salt to the wounds it lso appears that users are tired of seeing such posts. According to a recent survey by Facebook itself, audiences want to see less promotional content, meaning referral traffic for most brands could start to decline even further. And we all know how Facebook listens intently to its consumers. So now as per the hypothesis, the zero figure is looming large.

‘Mass Marketing’ in ICU, taking its last breadth

If Facebook is not profitable for branding anymore then what it offers to the brands? Many marketers now-a-days view the social network as another paid channel but with budgets becoming tighter, the latest situation brings up an old conundrum; why would one pay for something theyâve had for free for so long? Brands know their audiences are there, talking away on Facebook, but becoming part of the conversation is proving very tricky. The netizens have also become wiser. They are aware of the potential communications they can block so while brands strive for transparency they are finding it harder to control their online message as privacy laws become tighter. This adds to the lack of control and an inability to steer mass marketing via the social network.

They are aware of the potential communications they can block so while brands strive for transparency they are finding it harder to control their online message as privacy laws become tighter. This adds to the lack of control and an inability to steer mass marketing via the social network.

Yet Facebook fans just can’t be ignored. They still have an incremental value, as proven by a ComScore study which found that one retailer’s Facebook fans were 27 per cent more likely than a control group to make a purchase in the four weeks following a paid campaign. However, this type of result is never guaranteed and can prove costly. We would all love for our content to be shared regularly, reaching new profitable customers and to be talked about, but the truth is this is a fairytale today. Mass marketing isn’t the way forward; it’s no longer an efficient way of communicating with audiences.

We know that consumers want a relationship with their favourite brands, and to be valued and understood, and as such, they expect brands to treat them as individuals. “My favourites,” “wish list,” “recommended for you,” and “items you may like” are all common phrases that define todayâs interaction between brands and consumers. This should be a signal that itâs time to wave goodbye to the days of mass marketing and say hello to one-on-one conversations.

Mass marketing can indeed turn down a situation where brands will inevitably send irrelevant communications and thus turn away the customers even the existing ones. According to many studies, it has been found that 52 per cent of consumers have been sent irrelevant offer and that 37 per cent would disengage with brands that targeted them with poor communications. Often without realising it, brands are turning off their highly profitable and loyal customers that research shows drive up to 40% of revenue. The thought of sending a loyal, profitable customer, or as we call them a “VIP”, details of a product thatâs just gone into the sale but which they bought at full price, is simply spine-shudderingly embarrassing.

‘Like’ is backdated, ‘Know’ is the new kid in town

Getting and chasing for more and more likes on social pages is an old tradition now, brands should need to take their customer data, and make sense of it all to target them with messages that are highly personal, and relevant to them. Youâve got to micro-segment your customers to truly establish the behavioural and buying patterns of each group. Armed with this knowledge youâll be ready to target audiences with appropriate campaign material at the most relevant point in their customer journey to try and win them back, or even better, make them loyal, repeat purchasers. There’s a reason that only paid social posts get targeting options – that’s where the value is!

It’s been so long that digital marketers have craved the ability to make informed decisions on spending to convert, retain or win back customers and the technology exists now to do this. Time has now come to make marter decisions about specific customer segments to drive loyalty, revenue and growth.

Facebook is all time favourite

If we think of the situation as a crossroads (as mentioned above), deciding where your future lies will become much clearer. Take a left at the crossroads and you can continue on the mass marketing, headache-induced route thatâs full of consumers and competitors, all shouting over one another to have their say. Take a right and you will be greeted by each customer, eager to talk to you and ready to listen.

Despite all the problematic changes and algorithm updates on FB, it still remains as one of the key drivers in digital marketing. By using the Smart Insight Data, brands can reach customers in real-time with more accurately personalised material and at a point in time when they are more likely to be receptive and make a purchase. Email responses, web behaviour, purchase history and product affinity can all be enhanced with Facebookâs own profile data to create a true one-to-one customer experience.

The social network can also be a profitable channel for acquiring new customers but what marketers struggle to do are turn non-responsive contacts and one-time buyers, into profitable customers. Facebook can also become a highly effective channel for retention marketing by breathing new life into other channels that may have failed to grab their audienceâs attention.

The declining organic growth on Facebook and the skepticism surrounding the fact that it might hit zero, is just not a problem for brands and marketers. Being part of the conversation is vital today but the focus must be on treating your customers as individuals. We know that this approach works for email campaigns so itâs time to take it to Facebook. By understanding behaviours in real-time and developing relevant personalised content, brands can harness the power of social media to win customers back, while cultivating fresh business opportunities. The technology is here to fully integrate Facebook with marketing campaigns, and digital marketers should make sure they are fully equipped and ready to take on the opportunities this presents. Itâs time to bring back some control and get personal on Facebook.

posts.title: Mobile Friendly Website Design Types: A Glimpse
posts.title_plain: Mobile Friendly Website Design Types: A Glimpse
posts.content:
With the growing use of the multimedia sets and mobile technologies things are changing fast in digital marketing. Gone are the days when accessing internet required you to switch on your desktop or your laptop. Now with the blink of your eye you can go online, surf about your query and even buy the product of your choice- you can travel the whole world on your mobile phone itself.

A major percentage of users who are online today are the mobile users which mean that it is very important for the websites to be accessed through mobile. However it is very confusing as to which technology should be used in order to make the website mobile centric especially after the Mobilegeddon scenario change. In order to help you out and make a proper selection based on your requirements and expectations, we have compiled some mobile friendly website designs. Read on…

  • Mobile Friendly Design:Mobile friendly sites are the ones which do not break when accessed on the different mobile sets. In order to hit the buttons on the website or zoom in on visual media, you can always pinch or zoom the screen. One of the key advantages of these types of websites is that they are low on budget and does not take much time for development. However they do lack in experience but then with ios7 coming up with the browser enhancers, they readily improve the user experience and reduce the need for experience based websites.
  • Adaptive Design:Adaptive designs are the ones which adjust themselves according to the screen size of the device where it is displayed. It rearranges its elements according to the screen size of the device. This feature is achieved through the developmental style. One of the advantages of this style is that it adapts to the different screen sizes of the devices. The only disadvantage of this design is that you need to have different content for different devices which is bit difficult to maintain in case of big ecommerce websites.
  • Responsive/ Liquid Design: Popular as liquid design, these websites adjust itself according to the dimensions of the different devices. One of the key advantages of responsive design is that it automatically adjusts the content of the website according to the size of the device. Therefore you do not have to face the issue of multiple contents for different versions of the website. Responsive design can easily adjust the size of the images and page content sections based on the width of the screen/device being used. There are a lot of similarities between the adaptive and responsive designs however the key difference is that adaptive design is based on fixed columns and screen resolution sizes on the other hand responsive design is not fixed.
  • Experience Design:An experience mobile website is a mobile formatted version to display on specific mobile device. It is a complete separate design and as a result it requires a separate content structure for display. This design is implemented by parading the content so that it can fit to the size of the screen. However one of the disadvantages of this design is that these sites cannot be accessed on the desktop as they are specifically designed for the mobile devices.

Depending upon your priorities, you can adapt any of the above mentioned design types. Although, a thorough research will add more proficiency to the selected design. Being mobile friendly is the call of the hour and to be right on success path, you need to adapt these changes.

posts.title: Embrace the era of APP development
posts.title_plain: Embrace the era of APP development
posts.content:
(Source- Google images)

Mobile applications have come a long way. Just 15 years ago you were lucky to have the game Snake installed on your phone (remember?). Today mobile apps have become so integral to both our working and daily lives that we find it hard to believe we were happy with such limited options. Recent research undertaken by TechValidate and commissioned by OutSystems, the âState of Application Development Reportâ shows that 43% of companies now rank mobility as their top business functionality. The research also shows that they are struggling to keep up with the speed with which mobile technology is advancing.

The enterprise has already embraced the mobile and app revolution; the majorities of businesses have created their first applications and are now looking at how they can integrate and bring those legacy systems into 2015. Organisations may be making the leap into the cloud or creating a responsive design site, but todayâs app development has to build on what we already have.

When as a brand we speak to customers we often find that they need a solution that will integrate into their current systems and the research also highlights this need to integrate. 79% of companies surveyed said they have to integrate their applications into existing technology with the majority of businesses having to ensure that their new applications integrate with up to 15 different existing systems.

Despite the plethora of pre-packaged solutions available, most businesses still need to either develop their own bespoke solution or to customise certain parts in order to match their individual needs. As a result, organisations are seeking alternative solutions to app development that will simplify the process while allowing for rapid development on a budget, all while taking into account existing technology requirements.

It was also interesting to read in the research that the dominant mobile architecture is now Mobile Web (60%) and Hybrid (65%) with only 26% of enterprises planning to develop apps using Native mobile architectures. Does this mean that the traditional application is dead? Of course not, but it does further illustrate that mobile technology is evolving again and companies need to produce solutions that will continue to be relevant moving forward. We think the latest generation of enterprise apps is a lot more forward thinking than they were previously as architectures such as responsive design allow developers to update continuously, incorporating a DevOps culture into the organisation.

Over half of the organisations surveyed planned to build the majority of their apps with a mobile component, so it would appear that smartphones are still the dominant force over alternatives such as Microsoft and Chromebookâs PC app stores, at least when it comes to enterprise applications.

How to speed up mobile development and meet integration needs

(Source- Google images)

In our opinion, a mobile application development platform (MADP) should allow companies to develop the bespoke apps they need three to six times faster than traditional methods, not to mention the cost savings over hiring an external development team. A good MADP will also enable organisations to develop once and deliver across all devices, whether that is native or responsive design, as it is important for organisations to offer all options and future-proof for upcoming developments.

Clearly this is a period of change for mobile app development. We wouldnât like to predict what percentage of development will go into the cloud or how important it will be to integrate the existing apps into future development, but what we can say is that this research shows that mobile is still the most important technology for the enterprise moving forward. Now is the time to invest in your mobile infrastructure and prepare for how you are going to implement a strong, cutting edge development strategy that prepares your business for the future.

posts.title: Grasping the e-Shopping trend
posts.title_plain: Grasping the e-Shopping trend
posts.content:
Shoppers around the world now expect omni-channel, multi-screen experiences from brands and retailers, with the average consumer using a total of five devices when making a purchase a significant increase from the 2.8 devices reported in 2014. This is according to DigitasLBi’s 2015 Connected Commerce study of the latest retail trends across 17 countries including Australia, China, India, Japan, the UK and the USA.

Consumers are now connected 24X7

Along with computers, smartphones, tablets and smart TVs, consumers are rapidly embracing wearable technologies, with 17% of shoppers revealing that they now own a wearable device – a figure that is likely to rise with the launch of Apple Watch and similar devices with the potential to offer new in-store experiences.

DigitasLBi’s Connected Commerce study also shows that in 2015 shoppers are increasingly comfortable going beyond the traditional e-commerce experience to embrace mobile commerce (28%) and shopping via tablets (20%).

Products and services that allow this new breed of connected consumer to act on impulse are also proving popular. The survey shows that in-store pick-up is becoming a particular favourite of shoppers, with 51% taking advantage of âclick and collect’ services globally, a figure that jumps to 73% in the UK.

“Customers want to save time and money whilst being able to choose from more ways to shop than ever before. Mobile is increasingly becoming the platform of choice for bargain hunters on the go, with 85% of those surveyed now using smartphones whilst in-store. A further 55% of consumers claim that smartphones have changed the way they shop altogether,” says Jim Herbert, Managing Partner of DigitasLBi Commerce.

“We also know that 62% of smartphone users would be happy to use their devices to pay in-store. With the launch of Apple Pay in US and the growing number of start-ups in the in-store payment arena, 2015 could be the year of mobile payment. Brands and retailers would be wise to take note of the fact that mobile is set to fundamentally change the retail experience.”

Personalising online and offline sales is the key to success

According to the Connected Commerce survey, personalising the shopping experience is the surest way to the consumer’s pocket. 62% of respondents claim they buy more and/or more often when met with personalised retail experiences. A further 27% actively look for personalised offers when shopping online and 75% log in to e-commerce websites that cater for their personal preferences based on previous behaviour (40%) or to get product personalisation (34%). The demand for personalisation goes beyond the online experience, with 70% of shoppers around the world admitting they are more likely to embrace new in-store technologies such as GPS and WiFi tracking if they receive customised benefits in return, such as personalised money-off vouchers.

“Personalising the retail experience and tailoring it to the needs of individual shoppers is a sure-fire way to attract more customers and boost profits both online and in-store”, says Herbert. “The bricks-and-mortar store is going from strength to strength and behind retailer websites and apps, it has become the second most preferred point of information for customers. However, the in-store experience needs to become more agile, more digital and more connected. Retailers need to get smarter about using data in order to personalise the shopping experience to increase sales performance.”

Not on ‘Social Shopping’ list…you’re backdated!

DigitasLBi’s study shows that social media is influencing an increasing number of purchases both on and off-line. Overall Facebook is leading the way with more than half (52%) of users now admitting that the social network impacts the way they shop, up from 36% in 2014. This compares to 46% for Pinterest, 43% for Instagram and 36% for Twitter.

Social shopping is also rapidly gaining traction, with 28% of social network users around the world claiming to have purchased an item directly via a social media platform. UAE & Singapore leads the way in terms of social shopping with 56% of respondents now buying through social sites. Other social elements such as online reviews are also gaining importance in the purchasing process: 66% of shoppers read them when buying online and 36% when shopping in-store.

“Peer pressure has always been a powerful influencing factor when it comes to making purchases and the Connected Commerce survey shows that social networks aimed at our personal lives rather than our professional lives are translating this online. Retailers need to ensure that social media is integrated throughout the entire customer journey and that they manage their social channels to make a real impact on purchase behaviour,” says Herbert.

The retail or popularly known as e-commerce sector has taken a complete 360 degree turn and now if you are not an e-Shopper then you must be from caveman era. To be in the race, you need to grasp the consumersâ need and hammer the iron in the right way. Consumers worldwide now want omni-channel, multi-screen experiences from brands and retailers so that a whole new redefined shopping experience can be unveiled.

posts.title: Mobilegeddon perils Customer Experience for Financial institutions
posts.title_plain: Mobilegeddon perils Customer Experience for Financial institutions
posts.content:
Earlier this year in the month of April, Google’s Mobilegeddon algorithm change took the whole online world by storm. Creating a lot of dissonance in the digital domain, this algorithm change indeed pushed all the marketers to get their site prim and proper for mobile use.

It was pretty much understandable that the furore surrounding the new mobile friendly ranking alhms has been intense and extremely worrisome yet those companies in financial sectors making panicked changes to their respective official sites in a desperate bid to beat the ranking drop could be doing more damage than they realise. The changes they have made or making, if they fail to optimise those, they could eventually damage the user experience resulting in lost conversion and disengaged customers or customers in line.

It is not a hidden scenario that already the traditional financial services companies are struggling to regain foothold amidst fast growing digital savvy online only new market entrants.

So where at one hand companies are trying hard to make their grip strong in the market, on the other hand some banks and some insurers are now observing conversion rates of upwards of 40% on mobile devices. We are here with this blog to ring a danger bell towards these unvalidated changes taking place in the chase for mobile rankings.

Mobile Friendliness could be an expensive mistake

The earth didn’t stop revolving on April 21st when Google’s much vaunted changes to its mobile ranking algorithms came into play. The so called Mobilegeddon change encouraged all the companies worldwide to go mobile friendly completely whereas considering the survival fight in this digital era, this issue should already be the at the center of any financial company’s online agenda.

The financial services market are already under huge pressure from online savvy entrants and in such situation, no business can afford to jeopardise any aspect of the customer journey as account switching inevitably leads to dropping customer loyalty and retention problems. A knee jerk reaction to Google’s desire for mobile friendly sites could be an extremely expensive mistake.

According to Motley Fool, a staggering 49% of the Fortune 500 companies’ websites do not meet the “mobile friendly” status, so no doubt why the financial service industry is comparatively more exposed to this dramatic algorithm change. In reality, the immediate impact of the new algorithm change was somewhat underwhelming. Many pundits suggests that it is just a phased change, so for banks and insurers desperate to retain top positions in Google ranking, making changes in websites may not be a 100% good news. In the thirst for ranks, they could end up in harming the user experience.

The glass is half empty or full!

Google was really smart in its definition of mobile friendly experience, it said that responsive design is right up there as a key requirement but it gives no guarantee for a great user experience. One recent optimisation exercise revealed that one motor insurer’s carefully crafted responsive quote journey actually induced a 5% drop in conversions – against the original experience that wasn’t even mobile optimised, any more explanation needed?

Undoubtedly, the rise of mobile-savvy financial consumers has rightly challenged the trusted traditional approach of optimising for desktop and laptops first (usually the majority of conversions takes place here on desktops). But see at this from the other way around, the financial institutions should view this algorithm change as an opportunity to improve mobile and tablet usability through optimisation, to build on the continued migration of customers from desktop to using other devices for both researching and applying for financial products.

Dear Google, regardless of how compelling your argument is, at a time when financial institutions are clawing back acres of ground lost to innovative digital only players, no company can risk damaging the user experience or afford significant loss of business. With mobile conversion rates hitting 40% for some financial services companies, it is essential to meet the challenge of Mobilegeddon successfully and that can be achieved only by optimisation and validation. ‘Where there is a will there is always a way!’

posts.title: Content Marketing Trends to Look For
posts.title_plain: Content Marketing Trends to Look For
posts.content:
If given chance to describe the motive of content marketing in one word then ‘engagement’ would be the best word for it, isn’t it! Content that entertains, informs, delights and stimulates your senses and reflexes can easily build lasting relationships that might drive the folks (reading or watching your content) to purchase your products or avail your services.

In fact, the underlying premise of content marketing involves three basic steps

  • Creation of content with a definite theme in mind
  • Publishing the informative and entertaining content like photographs, blog posts, pins, articles, videos, small series to name a few
  • Attracting, engaging and retaining existing as well as fresh customers/ viewers

We are sure that you have your own share of ideas; we just want to share some ideas from our kitty that might help you. Come, let’s walk along…

Holidays or International Days top the chart

[Source: Google images]

Holidays or any International day is ideal for effective content marketing because they occurs at a fixed time, return annually and thus involve predictable customer behaviour. For example, let’s talk about Mother’s Day. The day seeks to celebrate mothers, motherhood and all things maternal. Frequently, Motherâs Day includes family get together, events, shows and presents for mom. So if we look at it from a content marketer’s perspective then there are innumerable interesting ways to integrate the emotional day with content strategy and present a useful informative and engaging content. Tell ‘mother’ stories, start a campaign or a contest, create videos or simply post some write-ups and link them directly to mother and a child’s relation. Social media platforms like Youtube, Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest works best for the same. Consider few others and plan accordingly because this will work for almost any business or brand.

Weave stories

Last year, a Harvard Business Review article praised the Budweiser’s “Puppy Love” commercial campaign like anything. The commercial ran on American televisions during the 2014 Super Bowl. The video post on Youtube has more than 58 million hits till date. To gauge your emotional response, watch this cute little 60-second spot.

This ad was a huge hit because it hooked you up throughout those 60 seconds by using a classic dramatic structure, including exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and a final outcome- a complete story telling structure. Further, another Harvard Business Review article namely, “Why Your Brain Loves Good Storytelling”, truly supported the idea that storytelling could indeed impact your customers and potentially establish deep relationships that should eventually lead to a preference for your brand or business.

Need any further inspiration, our very own Microsoft is here.

They puts a human face on its business with stories about “people, places and ideas that move” the company.

How-to ‘Videos & Articles’ in vogue

It won’t be wrong to say that ‘How-to’ articles/ blogs and videos are the flag bearer of informative content marketing. In fact on a daily basis, people spend most of their online time on enquiring about something or the other on World Wide Web. These ‘How-to’ content can be simple, direct, flowery and presented graphically or dynamically. They generally related to your services and products and thus increase the sales or footfall. For example, let’s have a look at the page of ‘Asian Paints’ Inspiration Wall’ where the company gives tips and ideas for decorating your home walls. The page has more than 4K Youtube Subscriptions and a huge fan following across its social platforms. Check this out

Tag it with ‘Hash’

Posting a comment, put a #tag; posting a pic on Instagram, put an ‘Insta’ #tag; uploading a video on Youtube, put a #tag…phew!!! Hash tags are engulfing the whole social scenario; social media sites like Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook are flooded with hastags and why not they come with a purpose. These little symbols organise content around different topics, create a web out of it and helps in getting feedback. They also used to gather user-generated content as well that you can use on your ecommerce site. For example, you might ask visitors to your site to hashtag pictures of your products in use. The hashtags will allow you to identify these pictures, and you can reward the best examples with a gift card, a discount, or just recognition on your site or social media pages.

The soul of content marketing is to provide customers with meaningful and cherishable moments they invest on surfing or checking out your site. Also, it is a way of keeping them coming back not only on your site but on your social platforms also. So what are you waiting for, let’s get started!

posts.title: Experimentation is the soul of Content Marketing
posts.title_plain: Experimentation is the soul of Content Marketing
posts.content:
Look at the animation carefully, it basically conveys a beautiful message- ‘We see what we believe and to change what we see, it is sometimes necessary to change what we believe!

Confused, why we chose to mention these lines here in the beginning? You will get the reason as you scroll down to read.

In the digital marketing domain, content marketing has now become mainstream. A lot of global brands and companies believe in experimenting with content marketing strategies and constantly injecting in innovative styles to let it go viral.

Content continues to be one of the most important aspects of digital marketing; however the implementation styles are rapidly changing. To become successful, businesses have to understand this dynamic shift and develop content strategy that accounts for new changes. Taking risks is part of a pioneering spirit and one should be applauded for that especially in a world where the results are hard to predict.

In order to understand the value of effective content marketing in digital world, let us look at two great examples of content marketing initiatives. First let us run with McDonald’s Canada- ‘The Meeting Place’ campaign video. On March 24, 2015 McDonald’s Canada brought some strangers together with a delicious surprise with a hash-tag, #imlovinit. They set out to spread a little extra joy with their finger licking food serving people for free. Have a look at this wonderful campaign.

McDonald’s Canada showed that not only people from different genres and world can be great friends forever over good food but also that for going viral on social media, you don’t always need an expansive and lavish video, just a powerful message can work wonders! The video has grabbed over 5 lakh likes as of now and is on a complete roll. It was no doubt a daring move and evidently it got a well-deserved pat on the back and some very good positive publicity on social media platforms.

Next we will talk about Dove #ChooseBeautiful campaign. Few months ago, Dove released a video of an interesting social experiment. The experiment has challenged women across the globe to decide to be beautiful and then re-evaluate their self-image positively for the better. In the campaign, women at stations in Sao Paulo, Delhi, Shanghai, San Francisco and London were given the simple choice of entering through a “Beautiful” door or an “Average” door. Let’s relive the beauty journey!

The beauty brand Dove was quoted as saying, “Women make thousands of choices each day – related to their careers, their families, and, let’s not forget, themselves and feeling beautiful is one of those choices that women should feel empowered to make for themselves, every day”. According to their real time survey, 96% of women wouldnât use the word âbeautifulâ to describe themselves, although 80% would use that word to describe something about themselves. They not only strummed the right chords but also uplift the confidence level of several women. It was a beautiful ode to womanhood. The video has more than 6 million likes in its kitty and way to go for this wonderful touching campaign.

These two very different examples are a great map of where we are at with the practice of content marketing. One truth is crystal clear that content marketing can’t be filtered out from other forms of marketing initiatives. In the current digital age where everything is connected 24/7, the thirst for effective content has reached to higher levels.

No one can deny the fact that content marketing is powerful, pervasive and it is the epicenter of engagement that the customers are demanding from brands, alongside their growing expectation for transparency.

These two wonderfully executed campaigns that took the social world by storm has definitely set an example in front of the digital marketers that you should not be afraid of experimenting with new and innovative ideas. In this fast growing digital era, we need to be trendsetters and that comes with facing risks but risk is what keeps you young, right? At the first place, you might feel skeptical about the outcome but there will be triumphs.

The impulse of good content will not slow down in the near future and social media platforms will provide a primary medium for conveying the desired message. posts.title: How secure is your data on World Wide Web?
posts.title_plain: How secure is your data on World Wide Web?
posts.content:
Let’s all have a look at the videos embedded below before starting with the blog.

Wikileaks’ 10 greatest stories

Seemed familiar??? Remember the sudden outbreak of many important and confidential news stories by Wikileaks- an international, non-profit journalistic organisation, which publishes secret information, news leaks and classified media from anonymous sources. Back in the year 2006, Wikileaks created a lot of hue & cry when they first posted a document on the decision to assassinate government officials signed by Sheikh Hassan Dahir Aweys and the rest is history. After that a series of news explosions took place and left many in dismay. A similar whistleblower blew the world of Internet by revealing information on the largest and most secret surveillance program implemented by the U.S. Government- Edward Snowden.

Although, the release of many important information by WikiLeaks and other such whistleblowers brought some interesting issues into sharp focus and led to accusations and heated debate between its supporters and detractors. Some named it a ‘whistleblower’ and some a ‘spy’ and the whole world indulged in the argument whether transparency is more important than privacy? But one thing which was clearly visible is the leak of information which led us all to the question that ‘how secure is your data on World Wide Web’?

People and several organisations across the globe, buy or lease storage capacity from the providers to store user, organisation, application or personal data and here comes a term ‘Cloud Storage’. Cloud storage is basically a model of data storage where the digital data is stored in logical pools, the physical storage spans multiple servers (and often locations) and the physical environment is typically owned and managed by a hosting company. That means your online data will never lose.

The World Wide Web is alive with multiple facts and figures about how much data is stored hitherto. Suffice to say, the momentum behind data storage growth is not slowing down neither is it likely to any time soon. As the usage if internet is growing day by day, the number of cloud users is also increasing on a parallel track. Back in the year 2012, Gartner predicted about the paradigm shift from offline PC work to mostly on-cloud by 2014 and look it’s indeed happening.

Today we no longer use USB or CDs but take the leverage of cloud-based services. Online storage services have become a mainstay, as more and more consumers and business opt to store data remotely rather than locally. It is cheaper and doesn’t require any hardware or technical resources too, so no tension of maintenance as well. But every coin has two sides, involving a third-party vendor can come with a slew of risks and raises valid concerns over data privacy and security.

This is a harsh reality that any information exchange on the internet involves high risks of intrusion and fraud. And consider it as good or bad, the whole Wikileaks and Snowden incident showed us all that catastrophic data breaches result in loss of goodwill towards the data owner and immeasurable damage to the brand itself. Think over it- a same incident is beneficial for someone and disastrous for another one!

So the basic call is to not only store your data but also secure it. We need to think about how can we protect our confidential data to make sure that it doesnât get into the wrong hands?

Online storage services should take the leverage of multi-layer security for safeguarding any data both when in transit and in storage. These security measures entail a lot of factors as follows:

  • TSL and SSL encryption –TSL stands for Transport Layer Security which is type of encryption used for online communications. This encryption method uses cryptography for encrypting the data while transferring the data from one host to another over internet. The encryption basically prevents the data from being eavesdropped and tampered. The two hosts engage in a ‘bromance’ process to determine every bit of information traded is a verified secure communication.

TSL is the standard norm for online storage services and extends up to web-based email services, high-profile e-Commerce websites, financial institutions and many more. Those who value personal information should use this encryption.

There is one more encryption method for securing data and is the predecessor of TSL, SSL- Secure Socket Layer. As per your need, you can choose any of them.

  • US government’s most favourite, AES encryption- Advanced Encryption Standard is the encryption of electronic data. While TSL and SSL encrypt data during the transfer process, AES encrypt while the data is in rest or being stored on a data server.

In this encryption method, single electronic key is used to both encrypt data as it enters a server and decrypt it as it leaves. AES is more compatible as it contains 128, 192 or 256 bits for much more increased security.

  • Enable folder permissions- The folder permission allows you to establish permissions when sharing any files of information on net.

It determines what users (those are invited to enter the folders) can do with the files- whether simple viewing, editing or deleting the files.

  • Lock it with a ‘Password’ – Password protection prevents unauthorised access to your information.

Also, password should be logical and strong (including characters and numbers) and generally should not be kept on anybody’s name. The hackers can easily trace them, so think before you save a password and don’t share them with any foreign body.

These days nobody bothers about safe-keeping data physically as they can just save it online but for that understanding the various security methods employed by online storage services is imperative. A fair knowledge will not only allow you to select the service type as per your need but also gives you a chance to secure your vital information (whether personal or corporate) with much more reliability.

Your data is solely your data and it will be your decision to allow anybody trespass it. Data breaching has become a burning issue worldwide and in this heated situation, it has become inevitably and undoubtedly important to think about the security of your data on World Wide Web.

posts.title: Why do we need to hire a Digital Marketing Agency?
posts.title_plain: Why do we need to hire a Digital Marketing Agency?
posts.content:
Why do we need to hire a Digital Marketing Agency?

Business owners often hesitate before hiring a digital marketing agency and why not after all they will be paying someone else to do the marketing activities that they believe the-or someone in their own team- should be able to do. But a digital marketing agency can indeed be a huge asset for any company’s branding. Being present in the digital domain, they have the expertise to help you better understand your clients, making plans to achieve measurable results and take your company’s digital presence to the next level.

A digital marketing agency offers a lot of things under one roof, website design and development, apps, search engine marketing (pay-per-click, retargeting), search engine optimization, social media marketing, content creation, online lead generation, online brand development and management, media campaigns, video, email marketing, mobile campaigns and ROI assessments, to name a few. It’s all about a company’s visibility.

A digital marketing agency is composed of a tightly knit team of individuals, each with their own areas of expertise. Together, they can offer you a substantial body of knowledge and experience.

Graphic Design

It is a known fact that good design increases the credibility of a brand and for a good design an idea should come to life and breathe. That’s exactly the graphic designers do!

SEO

A big jargon heard in digital marketing every now and then. People hear ‘SEO’ and tune out and think is that really important? Yes it is indeed, if your website isn’t optimised for search engines, it’s really unlikely that anyone will find you. That’s how Google works. A digital marketing agency uses special tools that optimise your website to appear at the top of page one on Google.

Social Media

Social fever is trending and to make a grip on the same is extremely important in today’s marketing world. Getting hands on and planning a proper social media marketing strategy is what a digital marketing agency does. They have a team of multi-taskers, some who know all there is to know about social media. It is the backbone of any digital marketing agency.

Content

This is something which cannot be overlooked. We’re in a huge market and everybody is in the race but to be ahead in the competition, we should offer unique content. The digital marketing agencies try and understand what your audience is looking for, what questions they want answering and what problems they need solving and then they promote the content. And that is the reason why some content are way ahead of others.

Apart from these amazing factors, digital marketing focusses on marketing, branding and analytics as well so as to make the development from all angles. Now, the question arises that if in a company, an internal wing with proper man power and complete resources are assigned the same job and if they can do the same things then why a company needs a digital marketing agency?

As we have already mentioned that the first and foremost was digital marketing expertise but along with that there are a lot of other reasons (mentioned below) that truly justify hiring digital marketing agency.

  • A digital marketing agency doesnât have to worry about internal politics, budget issues, hiring/firing, and other areas of focus that a marketer employed at a business needs to be concerned with. One of the biggest barriers in marketing world! A digital agency is hired with specific goals and they need to meet those goals- that’s it!
  • Since a digital marketing agency works for a number of clients at the same time, they have the access to license enterprise software and the appended cost gets distributed amongst all the clients. So you need not to worry about that as well.
  • IF a company hires a team dedicated for doing the digital tasks, the employer will be responsible for the hiring, training, monitoring and possible firing of the employees but with a digital marketing agency, that’s solely their responsibility. Instead you can focus and invest your time on other valuable projects.
  • A digital marketing agency meets different clients, understands their needs, their expectations and hence is able to roll out the strategies accordingly. A proper strategy that completely suits the clients’ needs actually minimises the risk, shortened timelines, and reduces overall costs while increasing results.
  • Sometimes while working towards the objectives and expectations, many gaps emerges in a company’s way of working. Let’s suppose youâre an email guru, email winds up being your top strategy for producing results. You donât have the time to learn and experiment with other strategies so you put your focus where you know you’ll get results. But this is just not a scene with the digital marketing agency, hiring one provides you the opportunity to maintain your focus, but identify gaps that the agency can fill efficiently.

If we have a look at the greatest athletes of all time, we would find a common factor in all of them- they hire nutritionists, physicians, agility specialists, coaches, doctors and other resource for their better performance. All the external resources indeed help the athletes to achieve their greatness in their performance. Similarly, hiring a digital marketing agency can inevitably help you rev up your performance; fasten up the execution process and ultimately in producing amazing results that can’t be matched internally, otherwise.

The digital world is moving fast and to be with the flow, you need to be as swift as the market wants you to be! Also, it is impossible to look after each and every sector and complete the tasks efficiently and thus for your digital marketing, you need a digital marketing agency.
